snippet: Divisions over a measure to extend background checks for gun buyers are undermining support for what was seen as a compromise deal to ease passage of a broader bill.
abstract: Rifts within both parties over bipartisan measure to extend background checks for gun buyers are threatening its chances as Senate begins debating broad gun control legislation; some Democrats who are facing re-election in conservative states already say they will not vote for measure while Republicans remain bitterly torn between moderates who feel pressure to support new gun regulations and conservatives who are deeply opposed to them.

byline.original: By JENNIFER STEINHAUER and JONATHAN WEISMAN

lead_paragraph: Divisions over a measure to extend background checks for gun buyers are undermining support for what was seen as a compromise deal to ease passage of a broader bill.

headline.seo: Party Rifts Complicate Chances for Gun Bill Passage
headline.main: Parties’ Rifts Hinder Background Check Measure in Gun Bill
headline.print_headline: Rifts in 2 Parties Complicate Odds for Gun Measure
